Talk to Ravaedron by Fernbrake Cot

'I hope you will forgive my not waiting for you, [placeholder], but I was quite eager to present my gift to them.\n\n'In fact, I was in such a hurry that I spared only the very briefest of greetings for the Ranger Idhrien, who I passed on the way here. She was collecting herbs for the Dúnedain, and I promised her I would help her with that task once my own was finished. Could I ask you to find her and apologize for my haste, and perhaps to defeat any dangerous beasts that you might find nearby?'

'Greetings to you, [placeholder]. Ravaedron sent you to help me? He has a great deal on his mind, and he need not ask for any forgiveness on my part! But I would tell him this, if he took the time to hear my words: \qIt is not on your head to solve every problem in Middle-earth! Leave the land as best you can, and treat those who remain with as much kindness as you have to give. If you do that, you will sail into the West with an untroubled heart, deserving of the peace you have earned!\q

'That is what I believe, anyway. Perhaps the Dúnedain are in no position to say such things, for our duty seems never-ending, as if it will never reach its conclusion! But I think these words will help Ravaedron, though I find them hard to follow for myself.

'But if you will help me gather the herbs I need, my work today will go twice as quickly! Keep an eye out for them after you have concluded your current business. I do not want you to run afoul of any beasts while your eyes are locked on the ground!'

Idhrien describes the particular grass-like tufts for which she is searching, and tells you she has not yet looked to the east.

'Could I ask you to find the Ranger Idhrien and apologize for my haste, and perhaps to defeat any dangerous beasts that you might find nearby?'
Ravaedron is silent, staring to the east.

'I... I don't understand, [placeholder]. Why have the Stagshorns discarded my painting? Did they not like the gift I made for them? This is... this is very hurtful! Was I upset by our quarrel? This stings tenfold that, and makes me question our friendship entire! Do they not understand that I must leave this land, but despite my certainty of that choice, the leaving is still difficult?

'But... how could they know that? They have not had the experiences of the Eldar, or faced such things as we have. Their sorrows may be shorter-lived than our own, but... they are no less deeply-felt.

'I think I have realized something, [placeholder]. My gift was well-intentioned, but it did nothing to address the permanence of my choice, or to soothe the wound it could cause. I sought an easy remedy, but no such remedy exists, or ever has.'
